number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2011
												This game runs pretty darn smoothly on my GTS250 / 2.8ghz dualcore / 4gb ram system.  Played at 1920*1080 with 2x AA, Med shadows, high textture, high detail, V-Sync on, I get a solid 44fps average and the game runs VERY smoothly.  Ingame FPS benchmark gets big thumbs up in my book, esp for a console port.Control wise you prolly should flip the FV and QE keys just to make quicktime events more manageable.  This is a console por and it shows -- You can't move while aiming and mouse sensitivity is a bit whack but its MUCH better than a lot of console ports I've seen.  It uses GFWL but it doesn't work all that well (drops on accepting game invites from friends).As for the game itself, so far coop with my friend is VERY enjoyable.  Supporting your partner and working together to defeat bosses is great fun, and the item / money system works pretty well.  I can't say I've followed the RE history more than loosely but the story works.  Haven't beaten the game yet, but so far so good!

												What and how can you best describe resident evil 5 without encouraging the wrath of fans and or putting off new comers to series.I could tell you its obvious continual flaws but why bother when its equally as obvious this is how its developers intended it to be. Location, location, location is my personal demon as the setting of 5 or for me anyway removed any element of horror that both its previous and their after titles install. RE5 which i imagine as a result of RE4 has moved away from the horror survival to one of an action game which isnt worth the trade especially when you consider RE4 had both.Do i recommend this game, yeh. Do i recommend this game over other titles in the series, absolutely not but when all is said and done its all a continuing story so is worth adding to the collection if RE is your thing and you intend to invest more into it.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												Let me put this shortly:It's a bad Resident Evil game. But it's a fantastic Co-op action game!If you're playing this for the scares, there are other games that do scares alot better, you will probably be disappointed. If you are thinking about purchasing this, i highly recommend playing this with a friend. As a solo experience its an OKAY game, the AI is kinda dumb from time to time, so be warned if you are going in solo. It's just TON more fun with a friend as your back up.Things I dislike:- As mentioned above, the sometimes dumb AI- Controls. They take a little to get used to, at first they felt really wonky. One thing ive not been able to get over tho is    that you cannot move when using your knife/melee weapon. (I recommend controller over mouse and keyboard)-  Atleast when i played, there weren't that many people online to randomly play with. The game is old afterall- Its not a good Resident Evil game, not so mcuh survival horror. Some, but not much.Things I like:- Amazing Co-op action expirience.- Awesome unlockables that keep you playing the game more and more just to unlock them all. Costumes, weapons, infinite ammo for those weapons, filters that change how the game looks.- Managing your ammo and items between yourself and your friend.- Overall fun expirience (again, amazing with a friend)I do think though that the price should be lowered. The game is pretty old afterall. If you are going to get the game, get the GOLD VERSION from a steam sale.

Now you and your bestfriend are playing a section where you ride in a motorboat. This motorboat is quite fast! Contrary to what one might think, the rockets you can launch are NOT fast. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												Finally game was moved to Steamworks. I've dreamed about it since I bought this game. On Game for Windows Live I couldn't even log in so I had to create offline profile to save progress in game and I could play co-op only by LAN. Now on Steamworks all was repaired. It is one of the best cooperative shooter that I ever played. It is not survival horror but sometimes game could scare. You do not need quad core CPU to run this game. Game works fine even on dual-core CPU. Game doesn't work for Windows XP anymore, you need to run this game on Windows 7 (if you have less than 4 GB RAM install 32-bit version, performance will be better). If you like cooperative shooters I highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Resident Evil 5 carries on what Resident Evil 4 brilliantly reinvented. Survival Horror with a more action focused twist. This time the story takes place in Africa following Resident Evil newcomer, Chris Redfield and newbie, Sheva Alomar, as they intercept a black market bioweapon deal. What follows is the situation going from bad to worse as they encounter series antagonist Albert Wesker. Where Resident Evil 5 differs from the previous games in the series is it's use of co-op.  You could play the game by yourself and rely on the AI partner, but that's more terrifying than anything you'll find in this game. The AI will recklessly use health and ammo without a care in the world leaving you in serious trouble when it comes down to a tough encounter with a pack of enemies. Where it shines is if you play it with a friend, Resident Evil 5 is probably one of the best co-op games out there with a challenging, and reasonably sized campaign which will see you and your friend constantly communicating and relying on each other to get over difficult challenges. Even though the game came out in 2009, the graphics still hold up well today and the game's soundtrack is what you'd expect of a Resident Evil title. You've got your typical "creepy lab" track, but you also have tracks that fit the African setting. The game also comes with Mercenaries mode, where you (and a partner) have to kill as many enemies to gain points in a time limit, but it's probably one of the weaker parts of the game and not really worth spending much time on. Resident Evil 6's mercenaries mode is a lot better. Summing up, if you have a friend to play Resident Evil 5 with, then you can't ask for a better experience, especially if you play it on one of the harder difficulties. Playing by yourself is frustrating and not a lot of fun, so perhaps you should try Resident Evil 4 if you're by yourself.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												Aaaaah Resident Evil 5, how many years did we spend together? You were my lover since 2009 from PS3 especially thanks to your side modes.... you were one of the worst resident evil games in terms of story but you you do really entertained me.If you think i'm crazy guys then you're right but Resident Evil 5 is the classic game that you may love and hate at the same time.Let's do things in order and let me explain.If you expect to find a Resident Evil with the right of having this name then just look somewhere else. We have no more the classic survival horror structure here. It has been replaced with a coop action style game that totally kills the essence of what RE always was.The story itself is plain, not that bad for sure but totally far from the strong impact that the classic games had back in the day, however it offers replayability and entertains you as long as you enjoy running around shooting, melting and kicking the butt of your foes. The game is pretty challenging as well so is surely worth the try.If you play this episode you need to forget what Resident Evil was and look at this product, as i said, just as a funny shooter.The mechanics are interesting and casual gamers would surely enjoy this game.Anyway, what makes this game a very tasty cherry pie are the side modes: 5 alternatives to the main game that will give you even more chances to keep playing. My favourite was "Versus" mode, where 4 different players are called to arms to fight eachother in 4 different ways (Is up to the host to choose which one).This mode Versus had strong impact over the community and i managed to find myself thrown inside a lake of salt and drama queens that marked Re5 Versus as the main reason to buy a copy of this episode.Today the community has been strongly nerfed due to the years that this game has on its shoulder and even if after 5 years of 24/7 play times i reached the burn out i still miss those moments. Sometimes i try to play it again but i totally lack the will and the skills i got have gone so it pisses me off even more.I hope whoever buys this game joins the community and tries to bring a new life to it, Versus really deserves it and i hope that Capcom fixes the netcode of the game cause it has some serious crashing issues when trying to play online, sometimes you get disconnected randomly.One last thing, you will surely fall in love with: "IT WAS IN YOUR BEST INTEREST TO ASSIST ME". You will see what i mean when you play the game :P

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2013
												Resident evil 5 it's the climax of the series when it comes to environment quality, gameplay, cinematics and animations, weapon selection and upgrades.The gameplay is dynamic and compared to the newer games from the series, never gets boring, combined with a nice selection of guns and satisfying weapon upgrade system, Resident Evil 5 is definetly the most replayable game in the franchise, requiring up to 5 story playthroughs to fully complete your arsenal. Environment textures are nothing special just decent, but the athmosphere is very good overall! Characters are highly detailed when it comes to textures, wearing items, animations and even the sounds they make (footsteps, breathing, gun handling).One of the most remarkable features of this game are the very high quality cinematics, way above any other RE game from the beginning to 2013.When it comes to story, it has good and bad parts, but not the story is what made this game great. The co-op feature is  well made, also mercenaries mode is fun both with or without a co-op partner.Unfortunately, so far Resident Evil 5 is the last game in the series worth buying, the 2 newer games being a huge letdown in my opinion.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												This game is likely one of my guilty pleasures. I know people tend to hate the 'new' Resident Evils, but I happen to really like them.Prior to playing it on PC, I played it at least a 100 hours on Xbox, going through everything to get a 100% complete rating and all the achievments. Sadly, the appeal of those things are.. well.. gone, with this version.Sure, it was a fun run through but the lack of friends actually owning this port left me playing by myself. Which is good, but not nearly as fun as with someone else. That, and this version lacks the DLC all together. Two missions with new characters, new outfits, new challenges, and new filters, are all gone, the menu they used to be in still actually present in the game like it should've been there.To keep it short, I recommend you get it for cheap with a friend and play it through; it's still a great game despite allk the hate.[Update] I wrote this review several months ago, and as of that point, the DLC has become available. I don't recommend buying it for the price it's at as it is an old DLC set for full price for a game no one really liked, but if it ever goes on sale along with the game, it's worth a playthrough for sure.

content:

												The “Villain Most In Need Of A Hug” AwardAlbert Wesker. Need I say more? Best villain (Vas from FarCry 3 beeing only the second place :))As for the game, while it did feel a bit different than 1,2 and 3, it didn't feel THAT much different from 4.The setting mostly and the action elements that were constructed for the "ease of use" and in many people's eyes made the game a shooter.It's not scary, but I'm one of the people that say none of the RE games were scary. While not the best game in the series, it is surely one of the best CO-OP games in the genre in general.Which makes it a great game by definition, even if it didn't follow in the footsteps of previous titles.Mercenary mode was a load of fun as well, best one so far.Yes, it could be darker. Yet, I still don't think RE6 looks any better at all...I highly recommend this game, unless you only want hardcore RE action of the past, but than again, you would not be here at all.

												Originally owned this on PS3 and played / completed it there on single player.Have since bought this on Steam and have nearly played it all through in Co-Op mode.This game is meant to be played in Co-op mode as it makes it a lot more fun as in single player the AI can be a little slow on the uptake or get cornered/into difficulty (especially on boss fights)I use a controller set-up and find it very straightford and damiliar to use.The graphics are still good for its age and the story isn't too bad. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												This game is likely one of my guilty pleasures. I know people tend to hate the 'new' Resident Evils, but I happen to really like them.Prior to playing it on PC, I played it at least a 100 hours on Xbox, going through everything to get a 100% complete rating and all the achievments. Sadly, the appeal of those things are.. well.. gone, with this version.Sure, it was a fun run through but the lack of friends actually owning this port left me playing by myself. Which is good, but not nearly as fun as with someone else. That, and this version lacks the DLC all together. Two missions with new characters, new outfits, new challenges, and new filters, are all gone, the menu they used to be in still actually present in the game like it should've been there.To keep it short, I recommend you get it for cheap with a friend and play it through; it's still a great game despite allk the hate.[Update] I wrote this review several months ago, and as of that point, the DLC has become available. I don't recommend buying it for the price it's at as it is an old DLC set for full price for a game no one really liked, but if it ever goes on sale along with the game, it's worth a playthrough for sure.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												Finally decided to do a RE marathon since I had never really finished any of them. This one blew me away! I played it on a projector on the giant screen with 3D using Tridef software  (the default NVidia 3D was flat and very blah). Pretty good 3D and the graphics were amazing even by today's standards. The storyline wasn't too bad either. I like how they bring back characters and develop the story further. Difficulty level was fair as I don't play these to prove to myself I can beat it on "insane" or whatever modes are above normal. I kept trying to play it closer to its release date but just kept getting distracted. I'm sure glad I waited this long because I was able to play it on a proper setup, given how incredible it looked on the big screen. Excellent game and I had no glitches aside from having to switch over to the DS4 as the Steam and this game didn't seem to like each other.

												The “Villain Most In Need Of A Hug” AwardAlbert Wesker. Need I say more? Best villain (Vas from FarCry 3 beeing only the second place :))As for the game, while it did feel a bit different than 1,2 and 3, it didn't feel THAT much different from 4.The setting mostly and the action elements that were constructed for the "ease of use" and in many people's eyes made the game a shooter.It's not scary, but I'm one of the people that say none of the RE games were scary. While not the best game in the series, it is surely one of the best CO-OP games in the genre in general.Which makes it a great game by definition, even if it didn't follow in the footsteps of previous titles.Mercenary mode was a load of fun as well, best one so far.Yes, it could be darker. Yet, I still don't think RE6 looks any better at all...I highly recommend this game, unless you only want hardcore RE action of the past, but than again, you would not be here at all.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Death by reloadingRE5 is a great game spoiled by atrocious controls. I mean the worst ever. These are the main problems: You can’t move while reloading, aiming, or shooting; instead you become rooted to the spot and therefore hopelessly vulnerable to attack. When aiming the sight is often (although, oddly, not always) wrenched away from the point already centred so you have to find your target again. And you can’t jump or crouch unless prompted. What the hell is that all about? Also the AI is pretty poor. Sheva gets in the way more often than not. The UI looks like something out of the 90s and is clunky to say the least. And you can’t access the inventory during gameplay (although I understand the reasoning behind this it is frustrating at times). So what is there to like? Well it looks amazing. The graphics are among the best I’ve ever seen, with particularly impressive character models and animations. And, controls aside, the gameplay is enjoyable, with a good selection of environments, some pretty tough bosses, and a range of simple but enjoyable puzzles to solve. Ammo is often scarce so you have to be more thoughtful about your approach to the combat than in many games. Overall it’s a top-flight game marred only but it’s poorly designed controls and interface. Sadly these are so bad I can only give it 3 out of 5, which is a real shame.3/5

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												A mediocre game but a lazy port job. Includes a decent amount of options, however horrible controls. Movement feels sluggish at times in comparison to previous Resident Evil games; It is especially worse when playing with a controller, although it doesn't seem to get much better when using a mouse and keyboard.Aside from the port: The gameplay keeps you on edge. Enemies can approach you from ANY and ALL directions. There are various bosses you will encounter, and you will have several different, although similiar ways of getting past them. It can often become very challenging - even repetitive. You focus far too much on shooting your way out of almost every level, rather than considering a more 'tactical' approach as you may do so in previous games.One of the "better" things about Resident Evil 5 is the integration of CO-OP. I'll admit, it's a mess. Although players continue to suffer the many issues of multiplayer, it definitely seemed like a good idea from a player's standpoint - being able to play with friends can make the overall experience more enjoyable for some.My final rating is a 6/10. Why do I recommend this game? Simply put, it is a game that you can waste a decent amount of time playing, even if you won't be missing out on much if you were to pass it up.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												As a masochist, I find this game infernal and for that reason very pleasing. Visually, it holds up very well, despite being 5 years old now. It was commonly used as a benchmark for GPUs. Most of the classic mechanics are here. The Capcom philosophy of survival horror, that is, creating difficulty through sluggish control, is bad design, but somehow it works here. Of course, unlike in many modern games, health does not regenerate. You also have your infernal inventory in which to store your weapons and items. The game really shines in co-op such that I'd say it's the best way to play it for the first time. Aside from one or two uninspired boss encounters as well as some more minor gripes, any masochist will enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Short Version: Fun co-op experience. Basically a simplified rehash of RE4's best bits with updated graphics .Long Version: Looks extremely pretty. Inventory management is simplified. Merchant is gone replaced by a end of chapter shop. AI partner is ok, but best played with another human. Many scenarios & boss fights are recycled from RE4 but less fun. An entire level is on rails turret shooting including the boss fight with El Gigante, who makes no sense appearing in this game. Giant insects are back but are weaker & less mobile. Weapons are varied & can be upraded. If u liked RE4 then u might like this game. U can see the first signs of RE turning into a action game, but this is still miles better than RE6.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												I want to say that re5 is a good game but I just can’t. It comes very close at times but in the end it’s a decent action game, nothing more nothing less. The potential is there, I like the setting and the first two chapters are great, but overall the level design feels very basic and uninspired. The gameplay is nowhere near as fun as re4 which Is weird because the shooting itself is just as good but I think the addition of the real time item management and the inventory system being just nine slots its just not as good as the inventroy grid you had in re4. Also a fact that they completely removed the horror aspect of resident evil and made it primarily an action game doesn’t help. The enemies are not as interesting either. Because the level design is not very good they are just not very fun to play through. Sheva’s ai is pretty decent, nothing amazing you can’t rely on her for example which is fine you are not supposed to otherwise where is the challenge but if you give her ammo she will use it and hit her target, she is very helpful at times. The story is very poor even compared to re remake and re4. Wesker is such an awful villan in this game he comes off very comical and the dialogue and voice acting is very mediocre, cliché and chessy. So many moments in the story that made me either laugh at how awful it was or just sigh at how shallow it was. It’s an ok game it’s not awful like a lot of fans of the series say it is. There is fun to be had. 6/10 (Decent)

Posted: September 13, 2014
												As a player who owned this on console since the day it came out, I can say that this game is amazing. To all the crying fans who cling on to RE 4 and the past installments like their lives depend on it, suck it up. The game gets a bad rap because it's multiplayer and it's more action oriented. Either way the game is fun, and has a lot of replayablity. The only huge complaint I have for PC is that the game doesn't have any of the DLC's other than two of the four costumes (Warrior and Business). On top of that Mercs. is still a fun mode, be it alone or with friends. I'm currently working on getting a 100% (for the second time) in this game after already having done so on PS3.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												One of my favourite games of all time. Worth buying just for the mercenaries modes.Hawthorne School of Aeronautics is a closed flying school/airport located 5 miles south of Orangeburg, South Carolina. The school was closed in 1945. Today the land is being used for non-aviation purposes.The Hawthorne School of Aeronautics was a World War II civilian flying school, contracted by the United States Army Air Forces to conduct primary pilot training for aviation cadets. The school was under the supervision of the 58th Flying Training Detachment, Eastern Flight Training Center, Army Air Forces Training Command. The president of Hawthorne was Beverly "Bevo" Howard, who had learned to fly at the age of 16. The military designation of the Hawthorne school was the 2162nd Army Air Force Base Unit.In order to conduct the flying training, the school built an airfield along with buildings and other support structures. The airfield was an all-way turf field, with four delineated runways (00/18; 05/23; 09/27; 14/32). A large aircraft parking ramp and two hangars was also constructed along with a control tower and operations building. The school structures consisted of a group of one and two-storied wooden buildings surrounding an oval-shaped grass area at the northern end of the property which served as a parade ground.At the end of 1944, training of Free French pilots was transferred from Hargrove Van de Graaft Airport, Tuscaloosa, Alabama to Hawthorne. The unit was inactivated on 1 September 1945. During the Second World War, Hawthorne trained 5,924 military pilots, including more than 2,000 French Air Force students. For his leadership, Bevo Howard was presented the French Air Force Wings, the coveted French Medaille de L'Aeronautique, and later the Ordre National de la Légion d'honneur for his pilot training and accomplishments as an aerobatic flyer.The Hawthorne School of Aeronautics ceased operations at Orangeburg with the end of the war, however it went on to continue operations at Jacksonville, Florida, and Moultrie, Georgia. The firm eventually became the large Piedmont-Hawthorne chain of aviation Fixed Base Operators.The airport was closed after the war, and was abandoned. The two hangars from the flying school were relocated at some point to the Orangeburg Municipal Airport at which there is also an excellent historical display of the activities of the Hawthorne school.

Posted: March 6, 2015
												This game is the most frustrating pile of **** I have played in ages.The control method and inventory system so annoying that the real battle I had was with that and not the zombies.After an hour ****ing around with trying to get it started because the Windows validation software that comes packed in the game not working with Windows 8 and then having to create an account with them and then a few required updates I finally got to 'play'.Dealing with the issues I had with the Windows account software was more fun than playing RE5. The controls hamper the game so much that it is just a frustrating chore. Unable to move whilst shooting?! What the funk? Confusing item management between you and your witless 'partner' during fights and a control system that doesn't work at all well either using mouse or controller. I spent most of the hour I played this either watching cut scenes, fumbling around in the inventory pop up screen when under attack or listening to my character calmly voice over having a nice calm chat with some guy who was supposed to be sending in help wilst five zombies ripped at his face as I struggled to hit them (whilst stationary of course) with the melee weapon or swearing at the screen.Wish I haddn't wasted my money on it.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Resident Evil 5 isn't a survival horror game, but that doesn't mean it hasn't learned a great deal from the genre. Tension is the central element of survival horror games, and in the past it has been conveyed by the gloomy settings, the sense of isolation, and the frustratingly clunky camera angles and controls--all RE5 does differently is convey this feeling through other outlets. Having a partner introduces new types of tension, because you're forced to rely on each other's support, find ways to manage both of your inventories during battles, and cover larger areas since enemies can appear from almost anywhere. Waves of enemies wax and wane with just the right frequency, and while the brightly lit environments make them less scary, they can be tough to deal with because they attack in large numbers and are smarter, faster, and stronger than their counterparts in previous games. Major encounters and boss fights are doled out with excellent pacing, and since you're never sure what to expect around the corner, you have to remain vigilant. The active inventory management system helps keep that anxiety up as well.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2011
												Zombie blasting fun. The good news: the graphics are great, the gameplay keeps you engaged and the music really works. The bad news: the story is okay at best, the AI is dumb and the inventory system made me want to shoot my partner, not to mention the whole armor issue. Recommended if you're a RE fan and worth a go even if you haven't kept up with the story. And if nothing else, Sheva is always fun to just gawk at.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2013
												A solid co-op TBS that gets a lot of blind hate from Resident Evil purists, and more deservingly, from those that say it's a reskinned and lesser version of Resident Evil 4.Despite that, I found it thoroughly enjoyable, playing through the game multiple times, and accruing more than 100 hours. This is thanks in large part to: Impressive visuals, a fantastic porting job (game runs silky smooth even on average hardware), addictive and responsive shootan/melee mechanics, enjoyable co-op, large weapon variety and customisation and one of the greatest bossfights ever (7 minute Wesker <3)It is brought down somewhat with cutscene QTEs, mandatory on-rails shooting segments, hamfisted cover system in the last quarter of the game and not having nearly enough Wesker.Mercenaries mode is also balls to the wall awesome, plenty of unlockable levels and characters (and you get to play as Weskerfu :3c)

Posted: February 19, 2011
												I like this game, but the progress feels slow.  It is almost as though half of this game was made awesome and fun and the other half was made boring and slow.  I just wish I could skip the boring and slow levels.  This game would be much more fun if they did not use very old game mechanics.  In today's gaming, no one wants to see an animation of picking up gun bullets for the 30th time in 5 mins, should get it by being near it ect.  Almost the combat feels sluggish in an attempt to make you feel powerless, they could have counterd this with a built in hand to hand combat system alike "Condemed Criminal Origins".  I enjoyed the coop very much but struggle with playing single player due to the feeling as though I was driving a tank instead of an agile man.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Resident Evil 5 is very much a love it or hate it part of the Resident Evil franchise. There are many reasons for this, most notably starting with Resident Evil 4 and the series departure from pure scare tactics into a more story driven, fight off zombie hordes sort of affair.I find that this sort of evolution actually makes sense as the games stay contained within the same universe. When zombies, the c-virus, las plagas, etc become common knowledge, it becomes much harder for the characters in that world to become outright scared. This also translates to the players growing up with the games. Whether it was the dogs jumping through windows in Resident Evil 1, the menacing lickers of RE2 or the constant stress of being hunted down by Nemesis in RE3, we've grown up with this series and it's very hard to throw a curve ball at us. We aren't the 10-14 year olds with wild imaginations anymore.So with Resident Evil 5, it follows the natural course of, we know there are weird creatures afoot, it's down to us to locate the source to try and put an end to it. And I find the story telling and voice acting to be very well done. It can be a bit campy but Resident Evil 5 wasn't going for a "The Last of Us" feel or story narrative. Now when it comes to gameplay, I actually find it to be somewhat more realistic than many of the shooters and FPS games out there. You are not controlling a platoon of soldiers, you are two trained mercenaries (for all intents and purposes), using strategic fire to subdue your enemies. An argument could be made that you should be able to move and fire at the same time, however in most military skirmishes, soldiers will set themselves up for a shot then move to the next vantage point. Shooting and moving, little own running, at the same time greatly diminishes accuracy and wastes ammo. With this in mind, the enemy AI is designed for this sort of combat. At no time in the game do I feel that because of this style of combat, I am severely limited/hindered as a result. I adapt to the gameplay, learn it's nuances and continue on. I enjoy it! You might look at my hours count here and think that I might be off base a bit or not enough experience with the game to make a full review such as this. However, I started off the with 360 version of the game, got the PS3 version, and now the PC version. Graphically, the PC version is much more impressive especially with the improved framerates. Not having as many friends on Steam versus PS3 or 360, I tended to play the console versions more often. Which leads to my one complaint towards the game.Your companion AI can be somewhat infuriating at times compared to playing with a real person and being able to speak your mind in voice chat on how to go about business. While the AI never truly outright fails, their waste of ammo and poor timing of healing items amongst other things can lead to moments of pure frustration, especially at the earlier parts of game and before you complete the game and can start unlocking all sorts of wonderful features (including unlimited ammo leading to your partner never wasting ammo again).In any case, I love this game, have played it many, many, many times and will undoubtedly come back and play it some more! Thanks for reading my wall of text. tl;dr- We aren't 10 anymore, scaring within the same universe doesn't work like it did on our younger selves, combat actually makes more sense than people give it credit for, wtf companion AI. Love. Much fun. Such awesome. Wow.

content:
Posted: January 30
												Story time: Myself and my girlfriend bought copies of this when it was on sale, mostly on a lark. We bought a few other games at the time and didn't think much about this one. By chance we started playing this first, and now, several weeks later, we're still playing Resident Evil 5 almost exclusively. Suffice to say, this game is amazingly fun for co-op.In regards to gameplay, everything is solid. Difficulty levels feel how they should, the gunplay is tight, there's a lot of strategy to weapon choice and equipment usage, there are hidden items and treasures all over to find, and bosses never really feel cheap or stupid. There are incentives to completing the game multiple times, mostly upgrading your firearms and unlocking infinite ammo for them, but you can also unlock some fun stuff like costumes, figurines, new difficulty levels, and filters (like black and white, sepia, etc).I can't comment on single player since I haven't tried it, but co-op with someone you can talk to is amazing. This is easily one of the best co-op games I've ever played. The only real complaint I have is that there are QTE sections that hit you with instant death if you or your partner fail an input, but after a couple of playthroughs you mostly memorize how to complete them and it becomes less of an issue. Still, they tend to hamper your enjoyment when you aren't used to them.tl;dr - Amazing game for co-op. Plenty of reasons to play through multiple times. QTE sections aren't fun, not that that should be a surprise to anyone.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10
												Solid game.It has the usual marks of a Resident Evil game. Zombies, tank controls, cheesy over the top♥♥♥♥♥♥ My only issue with this game are the Quick Time Events, which are the absolute worst of any game I've ever seen.The default keys are really inconvenient and you have to reset your key bindings to work around them. The cutscenes and actions also tend to switch up between the 4 keys you need to use to perform an action, so you can't just cheese through them.The problem with that is that almost all of the game's QTE against highly dangerous enemies tend to have a repetitive or slow element and a really fast one that's impossible to react to fast enough unless you happen to have your finger over one of the right keys. If not, you'll fail the QTE 80% of the time and usually die instantly or take massive HP loss.These usually appear on the screen for a fraction of a second, and pretty much 90% of my deaths while playing were due to quick time events. Incidentally, they're also the only time I ever rage quit the game.Never had a problem with any other game, but I guess it's because they leave people 1-2 seconds to input a predictable command, not 0.5 of a second to see which one of the random 4 keys it is and act on it.That and the port isn't incredibly good and I had a lot of issues installing the game because of GFWL, but other than that, it's a solid game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												It's strange how the direction to Resident Evil has changed so dramatically. From what amounts to open world exploration, with the need to gather keys, and clues, to uncover more passages; to an outright liner level design, with no doubling-back, and actual individule stages. It's just very strange, more than anything! As well--though Resident Evil. . .3, or was it zero? handled partners well, in this version it removes all the tension and fear, because you're very alert AI companion is by your side virtually at all times, and in fact I just stopped looking for enemies myself because I knew my partner would see them before I often would.It should be called. .something else; a different series, with different characters; because that's what it feels like. It could be successful if that's what it was, but what's here does not really feel like an actual Resident Evil game, and that's really the very worse thing about it!I don't know what the project leads were thinking, but perhaps they were actually turned into zombies during production. Especially the later levels feel, just not well thought out in basic ways. Like, there's these just knee-high walls preventing you from travelling across the path, and you simply can not cross them, even though any human--or zombie--could just step over those walls! It was really my greatest memory of the game, after the first level; just standing there, saying to my character: "Leon, please, just. . . just step over that wall. . .Leon, Leon, please. . . please. . .you're a super special-ops trained officer; you've travelled across the world, fighting monsters! Look, I can see the path on the other side of it; there's even a treasure chest there! Just. . just please step over this tiny wall!!!" . . . . .It's not even a  hard puzzle to get around them, it's just that no human would ever have trouble walking from one side of that room to the other; even if they had a broken leg! Ugh!!

												Story time: Myself and my girlfriend bought copies of this when it was on sale, mostly on a lark. We bought a few other games at the time and didn't think much about this one. By chance we started playing this first, and now, several weeks later, we're still playing Resident Evil 5 almost exclusively. Suffice to say, this game is amazingly fun for co-op.In regards to gameplay, everything is solid. Difficulty levels feel how they should, the gunplay is tight, there's a lot of strategy to weapon choice and equipment usage, there are hidden items and treasures all over to find, and bosses never really feel cheap or stupid. There are incentives to completing the game multiple times, mostly upgrading your firearms and unlocking infinite ammo for them, but you can also unlock some fun stuff like costumes, figurines, new difficulty levels, and filters (like black and white, sepia, etc).I can't comment on single player since I haven't tried it, but co-op with someone you can talk to is amazing. This is easily one of the best co-op games I've ever played. The only real complaint I have is that there are QTE sections that hit you with instant death if you or your partner fail an input, but after a couple of playthroughs you mostly memorize how to complete them and it becomes less of an issue. Still, they tend to hamper your enjoyment when you aren't used to them.tl;dr - Amazing game for co-op. Plenty of reasons to play through multiple times. QTE sections aren't fun, not that that should be a surprise to anyone.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10
												Solid game.It has the usual marks of a Resident Evil game. Zombies, tank controls, cheesy over the top♥♥♥♥♥♥ My only issue with this game are the Quick Time Events, which are the absolute worst of any game I've ever seen.The default keys are really inconvenient and you have to reset your key bindings to work around them. The cutscenes and actions also tend to switch up between the 4 keys you need to use to perform an action, so you can't just cheese through them.The problem with that is that almost all of the game's QTE against highly dangerous enemies tend to have a repetitive or slow element and a really fast one that's impossible to react to fast enough unless you happen to have your finger over one of the right keys. If not, you'll fail the QTE 80% of the time and usually die instantly or take massive HP loss.These usually appear on the screen for a fraction of a second, and pretty much 90% of my deaths while playing were due to quick time events. Incidentally, they're also the only time I ever rage quit the game.Never had a problem with any other game, but I guess it's because they leave people 1-2 seconds to input a predictable command, not 0.5 of a second to see which one of the random 4 keys it is and act on it.That and the port isn't incredibly good and I had a lot of issues installing the game because of GFWL, but other than that, it's a solid game.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
 Like Resident Evil 4 except tedious and awful.  --It feels  washed out and grey, with much less variety (hey, another African village/town!), with an inexplicable filter applied to exacerbate the issue, while RE4 had more colors and more environments. --RE4 had  a stand-alone story, and a self aware sense of humor about its own absurdity, where RE5 takes itself too seriously and expects you to care about its absurdly convoluted lore. --RE4 designed  its gameplay around having to stop to shoot to raise the tension, while RE5 feels like it's designed for a more modern third-person control scheme (especially in single player) but kept the controls because RE4 had them and people like(d) RE4. --Many of  the enemies are reskins of RE4 (and even RE2) enemies; the European villagers are now African; the Los Plagas looks less like a fleshy contorted blob and more like a centipede; The El Gigante has hair (and a turret section because everybody loves those, right?). The only interesting enemies (the new ones) are absent for most of the first half of the game (unless putting stereotypical Tribal African getups on enemies counts). --The game  is crushingly linear, and  the locations are sterile and empty, compunded by the really "gamey" way you can quit out to a loadout selector and shop when you die/complete a chapter. There's little incentive to look around and the environments are rarely interesting enough to warrant your attention. RE4 had bigger and more detailed environments, with hidden things and at least had you buy things from a person (and made you wait for long stretches before you could buy supplies). On top of that, there were multiple routes around and even branching paths (like when you choose between a pth leading past an El Gigante or one past the Chainsaw Sisters, or even in th opening in the village when where you run to changes what you fight). --RE5 added  co-op, but made almost no meaningful changes from RE4 to accomodate this, bar one neat section early on where one character holds a light and the other shoots,. The co-op does nothing to improve the game, and even infects the single player where you must deal with (and share supplies with) an unbelievably braindead AI partner, even worse than Ashley from RE4 --RE4 had  some pretty decent puzzles, but RE5 seems to think "put key in door" is a puzzle. --The bosses  are not nearly as fun or well-presented as RE4, and yet agin, the only interesting ones wait until too late in the game. TL;DR There is  nothing  this game does that RE4 didn't do better; it's a soulless and pitiful imitation. This game gets a  4/10  because it is technically functional, even though it's not fun. Seriously don't even bother, just get RE4.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Resident Evil 5 is very much a love it or hate it part of the Resident Evil franchise. There are many reasons for this, most notably starting with Resident Evil 4 and the series departure from pure scare tactics into a more story driven, fight off zombie hordes sort of affair.I find that this sort of evolution actually makes sense as the games stay contained within the same universe. When zombies, the c-virus, las plagas, etc become common knowledge, it becomes much harder for the characters in that world to become outright scared. This also translates to the players growing up with the games. Whether it was the dogs jumping through windows in Resident Evil 1, the menacing lickers of RE2 or the constant stress of being hunted down by Nemesis in RE3, we've grown up with this series and it's very hard to throw a curve ball at us. We aren't the 10-14 year olds with wild imaginations anymore.So with Resident Evil 5, it follows the natural course of, we know there are weird creatures afoot, it's down to us to locate the source to try and put an end to it. And I find the story telling and voice acting to be very well done. It can be a bit campy but Resident Evil 5 wasn't going for a "The Last of Us" feel or story narrative. Now when it comes to gameplay, I actually find it to be somewhat more realistic than many of the shooters and FPS games out there. You are not controlling a platoon of soldiers, you are two trained mercenaries (for all intents and purposes), using strategic fire to subdue your enemies. An argument could be made that you should be able to move and fire at the same time, however in most military skirmishes, soldiers will set themselves up for a shot then move to the next vantage point. Shooting and moving, little own running, at the same time greatly diminishes accuracy and wastes ammo. With this in mind, the enemy AI is designed for this sort of combat. At no time in the game do I feel that because of this style of combat, I am severely limited/hindered as a result. I adapt to the gameplay, learn it's nuances and continue on. I enjoy it! You might look at my hours count here and think that I might be off base a bit or not enough experience with the game to make a full review such as this. However, I started off the with 360 version of the game, got the PS3 version, and now the PC version. Graphically, the PC version is much more impressive especially with the improved framerates. Not having as many friends on Steam versus PS3 or 360, I tended to play the console versions more often. Which leads to my one complaint towards the game.Your companion AI can be somewhat infuriating at times compared to playing with a real person and being able to speak your mind in voice chat on how to go about business. While the AI never truly outright fails, their waste of ammo and poor timing of healing items amongst other things can lead to moments of pure frustration, especially at the earlier parts of game and before you complete the game and can start unlocking all sorts of wonderful features (including unlimited ammo leading to your partner never wasting ammo again).In any case, I love this game, have played it many, many, many times and will undoubtedly come back and play it some more! Thanks for reading my wall of text. tl;dr- We aren't 10 anymore, scaring within the same universe doesn't work like it did on our younger selves, combat actually makes more sense than people give it credit for, wtf companion AI. Love. Much fun. Such awesome. Wow.

												Zombie blasting fun. The good news: the graphics are great, the gameplay keeps you engaged and the music really works. The bad news: the story is okay at best, the AI is dumb and the inventory system made me want to shoot my partner, not to mention the whole armor issue. Recommended if you're a RE fan and worth a go even if you haven't kept up with the story. And if nothing else, Sheva is always fun to just gawk at.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2013
												A solid co-op TBS that gets a lot of blind hate from Resident Evil purists, and more deservingly, from those that say it's a reskinned and lesser version of Resident Evil 4.Despite that, I found it thoroughly enjoyable, playing through the game multiple times, and accruing more than 100 hours. This is thanks in large part to: Impressive visuals, a fantastic porting job (game runs silky smooth even on average hardware), addictive and responsive shootan/melee mechanics, enjoyable co-op, large weapon variety and customisation and one of the greatest bossfights ever (7 minute Wesker <3)It is brought down somewhat with cutscene QTEs, mandatory on-rails shooting segments, hamfisted cover system in the last quarter of the game and not having nearly enough Wesker.Mercenaries mode is also balls to the wall awesome, plenty of unlockable levels and characters (and you get to play as Weskerfu :3c)

Posted: February 19, 2011
												I like this game, but the progress feels slow.  It is almost as though half of this game was made awesome and fun and the other half was made boring and slow.  I just wish I could skip the boring and slow levels.  This game would be much more fun if they did not use very old game mechanics.  In today's gaming, no one wants to see an animation of picking up gun bullets for the 30th time in 5 mins, should get it by being near it ect.  Almost the combat feels sluggish in an attempt to make you feel powerless, they could have counterd this with a built in hand to hand combat system alike "Condemed Criminal Origins".  I enjoyed the coop very much but struggle with playing single player due to the feeling as though I was driving a tank instead of an agile man.

Now when it comes to gameplay, I actually find it to be somewhat more realistic than many of the shooters and FPS games out there. You are not controlling a platoon of soldiers, you are two trained mercenaries (for all intents and purposes), using strategic fire to subdue your enemies. An argument could be made that you should be able to move and fire at the same time, however in most military skirmishes, soldiers will set themselves up for a shot then move to the next vantage point. Shooting and moving, little own running, at the same time greatly diminishes accuracy and wastes ammo. With this in mind, the enemy AI is designed for this sort of combat. At no time in the game do I feel that because of this style of combat, I am severely limited/hindered as a result. I adapt to the gameplay, learn it's nuances and continue on. I enjoy it! You might look at my hours count here and think that I might be off base a bit or not enough experience with the game to make a full review such as this. However, I started off the with 360 version of the game, got the PS3 version, and now the PC version. Graphically, the PC version is much more impressive especially with the improved framerates. Not having as many friends on Steam versus PS3 or 360, I tended to play the console versions more often. Which leads to my one complaint towards the game.Your companion AI can be somewhat infuriating at times compared to playing with a real person and being able to speak your mind in voice chat on how to go about business. While the AI never truly outright fails, their waste of ammo and poor timing of healing items amongst other things can lead to moments of pure frustration, especially at the earlier parts of game and before you complete the game and can start unlocking all sorts of wonderful features (including unlimited ammo leading to your partner never wasting ammo again).In any case, I love this game, have played it many, many, many times and will undoubtedly come back and play it some more! Thanks for reading my wall of text. tl;dr- We aren't 10 anymore, scaring within the same universe doesn't work like it did on our younger selves, combat actually makes more sense than people give it credit for, wtf companion AI. Love. Much fun. Such awesome. Wow.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30
												Story time: Myself and my girlfriend bought copies of this when it was on sale, mostly on a lark. We bought a few other games at the time and didn't think much about this one. By chance we started playing this first, and now, several weeks later, we're still playing Resident Evil 5 almost exclusively. Suffice to say, this game is amazingly fun for co-op.In regards to gameplay, everything is solid. Difficulty levels feel how they should, the gunplay is tight, there's a lot of strategy to weapon choice and equipment usage, there are hidden items and treasures all over to find, and bosses never really feel cheap or stupid. There are incentives to completing the game multiple times, mostly upgrading your firearms and unlocking infinite ammo for them, but you can also unlock some fun stuff like costumes, figurines, new difficulty levels, and filters (like black and white, sepia, etc).I can't comment on single player since I haven't tried it, but co-op with someone you can talk to is amazing. This is easily one of the best co-op games I've ever played. The only real complaint I have is that there are QTE sections that hit you with instant death if you or your partner fail an input, but after a couple of playthroughs you mostly memorize how to complete them and it becomes less of an issue. Still, they tend to hamper your enjoyment when you aren't used to them.tl;dr - Amazing game for co-op. Plenty of reasons to play through multiple times. QTE sections aren't fun, not that that should be a surprise to anyone.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10
												Solid game.It has the usual marks of a Resident Evil game. Zombies, tank controls, cheesy over the top♥♥♥♥♥♥ My only issue with this game are the Quick Time Events, which are the absolute worst of any game I've ever seen.The default keys are really inconvenient and you have to reset your key bindings to work around them. The cutscenes and actions also tend to switch up between the 4 keys you need to use to perform an action, so you can't just cheese through them.The problem with that is that almost all of the game's QTE against highly dangerous enemies tend to have a repetitive or slow element and a really fast one that's impossible to react to fast enough unless you happen to have your finger over one of the right keys. If not, you'll fail the QTE 80% of the time and usually die instantly or take massive HP loss.These usually appear on the screen for a fraction of a second, and pretty much 90% of my deaths while playing were due to quick time events. Incidentally, they're also the only time I ever rage quit the game.Never had a problem with any other game, but I guess it's because they leave people 1-2 seconds to input a predictable command, not 0.5 of a second to see which one of the random 4 keys it is and act on it.That and the port isn't incredibly good and I had a lot of issues installing the game because of GFWL, but other than that, it's a solid game.

												We now live in a world where the original, GFWL version of a game is superior to its newer Steamworks iteration. What the hell, Capcom. This version's .exe still redirects to GFWL's servers, so you're going to have to install all that crap again. Afterwards, an unsightly launcher will still be present on your desktop, displaying errors, but its okay, because the game will boot up. But prior to this, I had to drop a .dll file into my install directory or the GFWL installation would crap out? What even? They've also gutted DX10 support in this one and apparently Versus mode or split screen co-op is also borked?Add to the fact that the game still costs $20 vanilla, or $30 with DLC, 5+ years after release. I paid ~$2 CDN in a bundle for this so whatever, plus the game underneath is still pretty decent.It's like a way, way less charming and way, way less tightly refined version of RE4. Instead of Ashley being unobtrusive and super annoying, you have sassy not-Ada being a mule for your gear. Instead of Leon's glorious bishie sparkles, you have Chris punching boulders. Instead of being in not-Spain, you're in some place called Kijiji fighting the Ebola Corporation or whatever.Steep sale only or get it on PS3/360 instead.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												A slightly souless successor to the epic Resident Evil 4. Resident Evil 5 stumbles around trying to recreate what was loved about Resident Evil 4, either by adapting from certain elements or completely copying the exact same events.Thing is that it sort of works. You have the same combat as Res 4, same sort of atmosphere and style, it's all in there and works in the gameplay's favour. However Resident Evil 5's major flaw is that it seriously lacks the charm and personality Resident Evil 4 flourished in. In story, Resident Evil 4 comes across as a B-movie with a sense of self-awarness that the Resident Evil series should pretty much just always have considering how blatently stupid the writing is (although funny as hell). Resident Evil 5 once again starts trying to take itself seriously in it's story and enviroment which doesn't really help since the story this time around has lost any of the mystery elements that kept Resident Evil 4's balance of action and horror and is now more action oriented when now it's more about straight up saving the world from ultra bad guy man person.Resident Evil 4 had it's set pieces moving at a very good rate. Soon enough while in the Village it becomes night, as new terrors emerge from the darkness, or the island and how  you delve deeper into gruesome and sickening labratories  and of course there is the Castle to which any absurd thing can be just slammed right in there at any moment. It's designed in such a way that anything could be in the next room.Resident Evil 5 doesn't really have anything new or continiously varied to it, and with the atmosphere now being kind of dead, there isn't too much to be remembered. The game for the most part repeats the same set pieces (Village, mines, labs) without adding to much to the mix or having the same twists and turns each place could have. There is really nothing in this game that could take you by suprise. Is the game fun? I guess it depends from how much you can get out of it. It's more arcadey this time around, more bent on action than survival and atmosphere, plus a new co-op feature which at the most is "neat and occasionally enjoyable" while also being "a completely destructing element". Cooping with a buddy CAN be fun, sure all atmosphere of horror is now completely dead and burried at least 60 feet under concrete, but meh, it can work out as an action game. The partner AI however is so absurdly bad that it forces me to make a really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ joke that questions whether or not the partner AI was symbolism of the mindless zombies of the past because you're AI partner clearly does not have a functioning ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mind.You're AI partner can shoot the things. That's about it. It will shoot the things, and can do nothing else. Want to give your partner a weapon to help with shooting the things? She (your partner Sheva) will use her pistol unless either 1. She runs out of ammo for the pistol (although sometimes will literally go find pistol ammo to use over using her fully stocked shotgun) or 2. You take the pistol away from her forcing the AI to use the other weapons. It's actually really astounding. Well, what else is there? A new inventory system. The cache case system is now thrown out and replaced with a real time 9 slot inventory overlay. This benefits the online play and the balance of pacing but also makes room for some massively stupid moments considering that every single item can take up a single space, aside from treasures. Occasionally you have to do trade offs if you have a full inventory and you gotta keep constantly switching around items just to either get some ammo, or health, or what have you. Possibly the stupidest part of all the inventory system is that armor takes up a inventory space. Beyond making no logical sense in any known universe, it is also obviously ridiculously inconvenience.So that's Resident Evil 5. It's not techincally bad, but it's hallow and forgettable. Mediocre overall. That, and Resident Evil 4 got it's HD re-release on pc so there is no reason to not buy that.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												Capcom really doesn't support this game.  You'll want to download some of maluc's patches for . . . various things. (Note:  A comment on this review stated maluc patches break the game for Windows XP.  So be awarre, and if you have Windows XP maybe don't use maluc patches)  There are bugs in this port, like teleporting doors in multiplayer (breaks your game in amazing ways you wouldn't even think possible), essential enemy in 6-3 not appearing to drop an essential keycard (there is a workaround but only if you're pretty well versed) &c &c &cThe game itself is pretty nice, looks OK in my opinion, plays decently.  If you really really like the game you can overlook a lot of the faults . . . sort of.  But then, if you feel that strongly this negative review will not dissuade you.For anyone that's on the fence - well, it's true a lot of companies don't give proper support to ports.  But if you think you're going to be able to fix a problem if you do have one from official support, better think again.Personally I really liked the game for its gameplay.  But just because I personally like the game and continue to play it doesn't mean I can quite in good conscience recommend a middling port that has some serious flaws.

Rank: 3/10Recommendation(s): Don't play this game.Major Theme: Who was smoking what, when?Bought at Price: $8.81 (Humble Bundle $0.98/game)This game from the controls, to the graphics, to Games for Windows Life.. Just isn't right.I patched the game to remove the need for GFWL, which for some reason is still required to port saves according to the developers. After that, I discovered that the controls are some of the worse of I've used. Sensitivity changes on the fly (who knows why), the FoV is like taping the screen to your face, and control layout with a keyboard and mouse is worse than Call of Duty Black Ops. Add on top that you stop moving when you aim, I'm just happy to know that I gave all my money to Humble and Charity.You will only buy this game for the love of the series, or you seriously like console ports.The best part about the game was when I uninstalled it. You will find that the calling part is the 2nd most enjoyable part when you get to annoy your partner.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												This game is a soulless co-op horror shooter featuring our old friends: Chris Redfield, Albert Wesker, Jill Valentine and a random african girl who I couldn't care less about. I can't put my finger on it, but something is very wrong with this whole game. Maybe the atmosphere, or the fact that there's too much action in it for a Resident Evil game.The story of the game is actually a milestone in the series, but it lacks the epicness and the presentation is poor.  I mean come on, you can't be serious to kill Albert Wesker without Jill being a part in the actual fight, or any other main character whatsoever. Having a random new character doing half of the job... I'd rather take more cliche. With this game Resident Evil offically turned into a guilty pleasure franchise of mine, but I still can't like this game. It has lost the spirit, and except the final boss there isn't anything memorable really, it's a big shame.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												If one day, the world were filling out hordes of zombies wandering around the streets, Capcom would be responsible for this.Its zombie bride started early within the industry, leaving most of companies behind who could not even realise what huge potential a zombie game could possibly be at that time. Resident Evil games went successfully quickly across the world. The franchise has never slowed down its pace ever since.When it comes to the 5th instrument of the series, with the style of the gameplay had been changed after each instrument of the past, the very soul of the franchise had been twisted into something else. There seems nothing to hope for. Yet, as long as the ‘Monroe-liked’ Jill is still alive, Chris is doing his job, what can possibly go wrong? Resident Evil 5 is telling an alternative story about Chris Redfield and the dark untold past of Jill Valentine. Moreover, it has been years since Resident Evil 5 was originally released. The game has been tested by thousands of players, even Capcom thought it should have been the last instrument of the franchise, yet, RE 5 remains still.As long as the ideal characters' figures still possess the heart of the gamers, the legends of Resident Evil will go on. It is a ‘FPS’ game after all, shooting zombies are barely the main objectives.Scarlet's Score: 8.0/10

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Those of you who're thinking of buying this game because you played and enjoyed RE4, turn around and walk away now. Let me explain to you why RE5 is NOTHING compared to RE4.I enjoyed RE4 immensely, I've played it hours and completed it 100% on all difficulties. After reading a few (in hindsight VERY MISLEADING) reviews, thought I'd enjoy RE5 as well. But boy was I wrong.First of all, there's no story. Or nearly no story. You just go from A to B and shoot things. Don't expect an intriguing story like I did, having played RE4 before. After a few chapters it'll get very repetitive. Also, there's no creepy, scary feel to the game. Everything seems to be in broad daylight, there wasn't even a single point in the game that I was hesitant/too scared to progress. Just run and shoot, easy.Second, while the overall controls are similar to RE4, which I like, they now put in a HORRIBLE inventory system. Not only does it look and feel very very cheap and unfinished, it's more of a hassle than an additional challenge of good inventory management, like it was in RE4.Third, the bosses and enemies are just, so, boring. It's like they used the least imaginative, probably cheapest, artists to create the monsters and bosses. Just expect slimy black tentacles. Yey. And I could've accepted this boring monster-design fact, if these bosses would at least prove a challenge to kill. But no, they threw in gatling guns everywhere to kill the bosses. You don't even have to rely on your gunmanship skills anymore, you just point and shoot with the gatling gun. YAWN.Fourth, I expect they ran out of ideas, because they just filled in some levels with vehicles: drive a jeep and shoot a gatling gun. Urgh. Steer a ship and shoot a gatling gun. Sigh. Stand on a deck and shoot a gatling gun. Whoop.Fifth: there aren't any cool weapons in this game. Each weapon feels like you're holding a toy gun, they don't sound good, they don't look good. And the upgrades aren't interesting like they were in RE4, because there aren't even exclusive upgrades anymore when maxing out your gun!The only thing I really enjoyed in this game is the melee attacks you can perform with your buddy online. Stun an enemy, punch him in the face. And if it's a stronger enemy, you can both unleash your melee actions on it, for even greater damage. Aaand that's really about the only positive thing I have to say about this game.So I think I'm clear: RE4 fans, don't do this to yourself, don't buy this game. Even the multiplayer, which is the reason why I bought this game, doesn't make up for all it's flaws.It's like a mental cringe, each time you discover how bad it is compared to RE4. It's a waste of money.

												I imagine most people would be looking at RE5 PC for the Gold Edition content. Well Capcom continue their trend of lazy PC ports, the gold content is not polished compared to the consoles version. Many of the DLC original assets are missing and Capcom have simply ported the games original assets were they could, this causes problems with character models like Lost in Nightmares Chris and Desperate Escape's Jill. Several voice clips are also missing such as Barry's lines. Some visual effects are missaligned like bomb lights.Don't accept it, don't buy it. Demand Capcom fix their mess.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2011
												Hmm, I have mixed feelings with this one. Why ? Well, it misses the horror from previous RE games and it seems more action oriented. Yes, that IS a shame. Don't get me wrong, it's not a bad game by any means; it looks superb and it plays great as well. It's just that there are (almost) no scary parts anymore. Blame the enemies, the co-op or even the sunlit enviroments, I don't know what it is. But it makes me kinda sad. I just hope RE6 will be about the horror again. Anyway, if you're looking for a solid third person shooter, or if you're just a big RE fan (not that big I guess, or you would've owned it already), grab this one.[Rating: 80/100]

content:
Posted: January 26
												This game is great but is stabbed in the heart by quick-time events and a few dog♥♥♥♥♥♥boss fights. The QTE Wesker fight is the worst and a gamers nightmare. The other main problem: no zombies. Almost every enemy is shirtless black guys. RE5 looks awesome and controls much, much better than any previous RE game, although 6 controls even better than this. It's action-horror and not survival-horror like RE1-3. Some people hate the direction that Capcom has taken the series, but 4 and 5 are still very well done games regardless of that fact. You can pine for the old RE days as much as you want, but a game like RE5 or RE6 is vastly superior in all technical aspects to the older games with their god awful tank controls. It could've just used some more horror. 5 isn't bad, just could do without the god awful quicktime events and sorely needs zombies, although a few of the bad guys are scary and difficult and the game is very well made overall. To this day though it remains a not very good port and some people have crashing issues still, myself included, although I did eventually beat it.7.5/10

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												While I would recommend Resident Evil 4 for its interesting, survival enough, first half, I'm definitely not going to recommend this one.It is fun to play in coop with a friend, sure, but that's also one of the reasons why it COMPLETELY lost its survival horror nature.Your first concern won't be surving, it will be slaughtering as many monsters as you can see. This is where the series became a third person action shooter (oh and now the monsters also shoots you back with firearms, in case it wasn't an action shooter enough)...Characters are absolutely the worst: - how they transformed Chris (in the end he also SMASH a giant volcano rock with his fists)- how they transformed Jill- how the whole Wesker thing ends... really irrespectful of how big of an antagonist he was- Sheva, the big booby woman I can't even remember the name of and the others...You want to play this with a friend so you can just have fun regardless of what game are you playing? (they could have called this game African Crazy Shooter 5 and none would have found similitaries to Resident Evil)Buy it then and have fun, you're going to share a few laughs with your buddies.BUT if...You want to play this game because you loved Resident Evil and just want more of its story and survival gameplay?STAY AWAY FOR YOUR OWN SAKE... this game takes the WORST part of Resident Evil 4, get it even worse and make a whole game out of it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Remember how fun and awesome Resident Evil 4 was? The terrible plot....the awful one liners from Leon..... How terribly written the dialogue was between characters....and the silliness/charm of the Merchant, or the interactions with Ada/Louis/Ashley? No time for fun now....we have to be gritty and serious....this all has to be taken very seriously, because resident evil traditionally has never been tongue and cheek right?Resident Evil 5, feels like a big step backward from the foundations that the previous game left Capcom to work with. Whilst the engine itself is fairly nice to play in, and the framerate is very good consistantly (in fact, years ago, it was the first major title I got to see in 60fps+ and I found it impressive for the time compared to how well most other games ran). The problems lie in 2 different places, and it is odd................Some spoilers ahead............Firstly the Content itself.... This games story, and the motivations for the antagonists ((strange looking white guy, some lady who works with him? (I think, or it maybe a partnership of oppertunity?) and Wesker)), are incredibly vague. Whilst it doesn't bother me too much on Weskers part as he's the mega evil series antagonist who does a lot in the background we don't see anyway, the other two antagonists have a lot to do with the "story" of why Chris is running around doing what he is doing, and all we get are vague references to "sample" and "outbreaks" blah blah blah. Whilst in some cases this could be considered standard resi, it was also done with characters we liked, had a charisma or charm to them, and with amusing voice acting, fans of the series can accept that. Similar screenplay coming from generic BSAA meat heads we've never met before, or flat boring antagonists whose voice actors sound bored doesn't cut it.We are also shamelessly treated to some "important" "plot" points regarding Jill, but they are dangled in front of us in a way that felt a bit strange, Chris having memory flashbacks (honestly I never thought he was that deep) to an incident involving Jill that seems to have some importance as to why she turns up in this game....the you realised soon after the game was released that Chris was in fact watching the trailer footage for the upcoming DLC in his flashback *smirks*.The only parts of this game where characters had any charisma about them, were scenes with Wesker. Honestly, if it were not for Wesker, I wouldn't have finished this game even once, it would have been too flat and boring. I will also genuinely concede that Wesker shouting "CHRIIIIIIISSSSSSSSS!!!" is possibly one of the most laugh out loud moments any resi game has given me, but it isn't much worth the hours upon hours of boring you have to put up with to get there.Now the second major point I would like to bring up is the Single/multiplayer aspect.Everything i've said about this game refers to mostly playing it with a friend online, and we must have finished that game several times together, and it was fun, though mostly for the stupid things you do ingame/say to eachother whilst playing with someone you know. I can't really say much about the single player other than when I last played it with the intention of finishing it on my own on a harder difficulty, the computer controlled ally was so broken. They wouldn't do anything they were supposed to which made certain sections of the game impossible to progress through. It is possible it might be fixed now, it has been a long time since I last went through this game start to finish.I did in a bundle, buy the DLC story... it was cheap, and I was curious, but honestly, I played maybe like 10mins of it before getting bored and just playing the HD remake of 1 instead. Since resident evil 1 / Code Veronica, Chris Redfield seems to be on the steroids and increased his hunk factor by 400%..he is more muscle than man....twisted and..(hah).When you add up and consider various elements of the resident evil franchise, all I can really think of is this...Leon...Resident Evil 4....Killing a chicken...equipping its egg to throw at someone...somehow doesn't feel out of place with the previous 3 games in mind. Everything in Resident evil 5 feels out of place when thinking about the previous titles. In my minds eye, I can see the progression from Leon in res2, to leon in res4. What I fail to grasp (in the context of this game) is the small concept of young adults who entered the Spencer Mansion all those years ago and had a small, narrow story adventure about zombies, now being world biological terrorist fighting squad trying to tie in ideas from a bad movie franchise, with crappy rail shooter sections thrown in for apparently "why not?"which all concludes with a fight in a volcano.I did not enjoy this product as a "resident evil" title.

Posted: October 31, 2015
												First off I actually really enjoyed my time playing through RE5 several years ago with a friend on the PS3, so I figured it might be fun to pick up the PC version and finally play it in 1080/60. Man... this port has some problems. First is that the screen will begin to flicker every 5-10 minutes, so you'll have to alt-tab out of the game to temp fix the problem, but it'll eventually happen again and again. Next is that even though Capcom recently pulled GFWL out of the game you'll still have to install the GFW client to get the game running, but at least you won't have to log into Live anymore. And I guess they pulled out DX10 support while switching over to Steamworks. Plus whenever you launch the game it'll all open a DOS prompt with an error message each time.If you're really interested in playing RE5 I'd say pick up a copy for the 360 or PS3 so you don't have to deal with this port's problems. Capcom has still made the original GFWL version available as a beta for this game, perhaps that version doesn't have the same problems.
